questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question_text:
Paragraph

When 100 mL of 1.0 M KCl was mixed with 100 mL of 1.0 M NaOH in an insulated beaker at constant pressure, a temperature increase of 5.7o C was measured for the beaker and its contents (Expt. 1). Because the enthalpy of neutralization of a strong acid with a strong base is constant (-57.0 kJ/mol), this experiment could be used to measure the calorimeter constant. In a second experiment (Expt. 2) 100 mL of 2.0 M acetic acid (Ka = 2.0 $$\times$$ 10-5) was mixed with 100 mL of 1.0 M NaOH (under identical conditions to Expt. 1) where a temperature rise of 5.6o C was measured. (Consider heat capacity of all solutions as 4.2 J/gK and density of all solutions as 1.0 g m/L)

Question

The pH of the solution after Expt. 2 is

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question_text:
Paragraph

When 100 mL of 1.0 M HCl was mixed with 100 mL of 1.0 M NaOH in an insulated beaker at constant pressure, a temperature increase of 5.7o C was measured for the beaker and its contents (Expt. 1). Because the enthalpy of neutralization of a strong acid with a strong base is constant (-57.0 kJ/mol), this experiment could be used to measure the calorimeter constant. In a second experiment (Expt. 2) 100 mL of 2.0 M acetic acid (Ka = 2.0 $$\times$$ 10-5) was mixed with 100 mL of 1.0 M NaOH (under identical conditions to Expt. 1) where a temperature rise of 5.6o C was measured. (Consider heat capacity of all solutions as 4.2 J/gK and density of all solutions as 1.0 g m/L)

Question

Enthalpy of dissociation (in kJ/mol) of acetic acid obtained from the Expt. 2 is

questions.subject: Physics
questions.question_text: Consider a uniform spherical charge distribution of radius $${R_1}$$ centred at the origin $$O.$$ In this distribution, a spherical cavity of radius $${R_2},$$ centred at $$P$$ with distance $$OP=a$$ $$ = {R_1} - {R_2}$$ (see figure) is made. If the electric field inside the cavity at position $$\overrightarrow r $$ is $$\overrightarrow E \overrightarrow {\left( r \right)} ,$$ then the correct statement(s) is (are)

option_texts.A: $$\overrightarrow E $$ is uniform, its magnitude is independent of $${R_2}$$ but its direction depends on $$\overrightarrow r .$$
option_texts.B: $$\overrightarrow E $$ is uniform, its magnitude depends on $${R_2}$$ and its direction depends on $$\overrightarrow r .$$
option_texts.C: $$\overrightarrow E $$ is uniform, its magnitude is independent of a but its direction depends on $$\overrightarrow a $$
option_texts.D: $$\overrightarrow E $$ is uniform and both its magnitude and direction depend on $$\overrightarrow a $$

questions.question_text:
A large spherical mass M is fixed at one position and two identical masses m are kept on a line passing through the centre of M (see figure). The point masses are connected by a rigid massless rod of length l and this assembly is free to move along the line connecting them.


All three masses interact only through their mutual gravitational interaction. When the point mass nearer to M is at a distance r = 3l from M the tension in the rod is zero for m = $$k\left( {{M \over {288}}} \right)$$. The value of k is

questions.subject: Physics
questions.question_text: In plotting stress versus strain curves for two materials P and Q, a student by mistake puts strain on the y-axis and stress on the x-axis as shown in the figure. Then, the correct statements is/are

option_texts.A: P has more tensile strength than Q
option_texts.B: P is more ductile than Q
option_texts.C: P is more brittle than Q
option_texts.D: The Young's modulus of P is more than that of Q

questions.subject: Physics
questions.question_text: A parallel plate capacitor having plates of area S and plate separation d, has capacitance C1 in air. When two dielectrics of different relative permittivities ($$\varepsilon $$1 = 2 and $$\varepsilon $$2 = 4) are introduced between the two plates as shown in the figure, the capacitance becomes C2. The ratio $${{{C_2}} \over {{C_1}}}$$ is

questions.subject: Physics
questions.question_text:
An ideal monoatomic gas is confined in a horizontal cylinder by a spring loaded piston (as shown in the figure). Initially the gas is at temperature T1, pressure P1 and volume V1 and the spring is in its relaxed state. The gas is then heated very slowly to temperature T2, pressure P2 and volume V2. During this process the piston moves out by a distance x.

Ignoring the friction between the piston and the cylinder, the correct statements is/are

option_texts.A: If V_{2} = 2V_{1} and T_{2} = 3T_{l}, then the energy stored in the spring is $${1 \over 4}{P_1}{V_1}$$
option_texts.B: If V_{2} = 2V_{1} and T_{2} = 3T_{1}, then the change in internal energy is $$3{P_1}{V_1}$$
option_texts.C: If V_{2}  = 3V_{1} and T_{2} = 4T_{1}, then the work done by the gas is $${7 \over 3}{P_1}{V_1}$$
option_texts.D: If V_{2} = 3V_{1} and T_{2} = 4T_{1}, then the heat supplied to the gas is $${17 \over 6}{P_1}{V_1}$$

questions.subject: Physics
questions.question_text:
A fission reaction is given by $$_{92}^{236}U \to _{54}^{140}Xe + _{38}^{94}Sr + x + y$$, where x and y are two particles. Considering $$_{92}^{236}U$$ to be at rest, the kinetic energies of the products are denoted by $${K_{Xe}},{K_{Sr}},{K_x}(2MeV)$$ $$
\text { and } \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{y}}(2 \mathrm{MeV})
$$, respectively. Let the binding energies per nucleon of $$_{92}^{236}U$$, $$_{54}^{140}Xe$$ and $$_{38}^{94}Sr$$ be 7.5 MeV, 8.5 MeV and 8.5 MeV, respectively. Considering different conservation laws, the correct options is/are

option_texts.A: x = n, y = n, K_{sr} = 129 MeV, K_{Xe} = 86 MeV
option_texts.C: x = p, y = n, K_{sr} = 129 MeV, K_{Xe} = 86 MeV
option_texts.D: x = n, y = n, K_{sr} = 86 MeV, K_{Xe} = 129 MeV

questions.subject: Physics
questions.question_text: For two structures namely S1 with n1 = $${{\sqrt {45} } \over 4}$$ and n2 = $${3 \over 2}$$, and S2 with n1 = $${8 \over 5}$$ and n2 = $${7 \over 5}$$ and taking the refractive index of water to be $${4 \over 3}$$ and that to air to be 1, the correct options is/are :

option_texts.A: NA of S_{1} immersed in water is the same as that of S_{2} immersed in a liquid of refractive index $${{16} \over {3\sqrt {15} }}$$
option_texts.B: NA of S_{1} immersed in liquid of refractive index $${6 \over {\sqrt {15} }}$$ is the same as that of S_{2} immersed in water
option_texts.C: NA of S_{1} placed in air is the same as that S_{2} immersed in liquid of refractive index $${4 \over {\sqrt {15} }}$$
option_texts.D: NA of S_{1} placed in air is the same as that of S_{2} placed in water

questions.subject: Physics
questions.question_text: Consider two different metallic strips (1 and 2) of same dimensions (length l, width w and thickness d) with carrier densities n1 and n2, respectively. Strip 1 is placed in magnetic field B1 and strip 2 is placed in magnetic field B2, both along positive y-directions. Then V1 and V2 are the potential differences developed between K and M in strips 1 and 2, respectively. Assuming that the current I is the same for both the strips, the correct options is/are :
